Just since this deal was announced, Iran has conducted multiple illegal ballistic missile tests. They've held American sailors at gunpoint.
The Administration seems convinced that endless concessions to Iran will provoke a behavior change. That has proven to be laughably false.

column1: Until Congress votes, the United States has not agreed to a deal. Administration should have waited to go to the UN. http://t.co/oDiHUkX2kq

Read my full statement on the United Nations vote on Iran today: http://t.co/E7mLgKFGkC
Congress must fully review this agreement before the Administration grants Iran those concessions.
The Iranian regime has waited years for a lifted arms embargo, allowing them to buy more weapons for Hamas and Hezbollah to aim at Israel.
The Iranian regime has waited years to receive the billions in frozen offshore accounts which they can use to fund international terror.
The Iranian regime has waited years for the international nuclear legitimacy which the Obama Administration seems determined to grant them.
The American people & representatives in Congress have 60 days to review this deal, agreed to in the Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act.
Coming on the heels of the Administration's seemingly endless concession-granting to the Iranians in Vienna, this UN action is unacceptable.
The Administration pattern: mislead the Congress, avoid the American people, and use extraconstitutional actions to advance their Iran deal.
I condemn the Administration’s decision to take their Iran deal to the UN before the US Congress in the strongest possible terms.
Today's UN vote sets the stage for sanctions against Iran to be lifted and Iran’s considerable ledger of past violations to be wiped clean.
Seemingly, the Administration would rather run to UN bureaucrats for rubber-stamp approval than make the case for their deal on its merits.
The Administration’s decision to take the Iran nuclear agreement to the UN before the US Congress is a grave mistake.
